title-group.article-title: Theoretical analysis of biaxial tensile properties of power net

article-meta.aff: 1Graduate school of Human Development and Environment, Kobe University, Japan

author-notes.corresp: Mari Inoue, Graduate School of Human Development and Environment, Kobe University, 3-11 Tsurukabuto, Nada-ku, Kobe, Hyogo, 657-8501, Japan. Email: inouoema@kobe-u.ac.jp

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Power net is a kind of warp knitted fabric and a distinctive feature of this fabric is its high extensibility in both wale and course directions. The main uses of this power net are supporters, ladies foundation garment, girdle etc. due to its high formability property. The theory of the biaxial extension of power net is introduced, in this study. And the theory is inspected by the biaxial extension experiments of a power net for various biaxial extension modes. The experimental results and theoretical predictions prove to be in agreement. The biaxial extension property of a power net was analyzed and compared with experimental results obtained by a biaxial tensile tester. Another sample was also inspected, and same results were given. The theory can predict well, especially in the forces along the tensile direction, and good agreement between experimental and calculated results was obtained. The theory by the simplified model might be useful for designing the power net, and with the various studies until now, this will be powerful tool for the design of the wearing comfort of ladies foundation garment and so on.

body.p: A power net is a kind of warp knitted fabric and a distinctive feature of this fabric is its high extensibility in both wale and course directions. The main uses of this power net are as supports in ladies foundation garments, girdles, etc. due to its high formability property. Niwa et al. have studied the uniaxial and biaxial tensile properties and stress relaxation properties of the power net and investigated the relationship between the physical properties of the power net and the wearing comfort of ladies foundation garments,1–4 and a phenomenological approach to the biaxial stress–strain relation of the power net has been investigated by applying a linearizing method.5 In this study, we describe a structural mechanics approach based on a structure model of the power net6 and the validity of this approach.

sec.title: The structure model
sec.p:
The structure of the power net is formed from four half-set threaded guide bars, the front two bars laying-in a nylon yarn, the remaining two bars laying-in an elastic yarn. Although the insertion of elastic yarn is only in the wale direction, the extensibility of the power net is high in biaxial directions. This biaxial extensibility is due to the special net structure. Photographs of the power net are shown in Figure 1 and the structure is shown in Figure 2. Figure 1.
Photographs of the power net.
Figure 2.
Structure of the power net.

The structure of the samples used in the experimental investigation is formed with nylon filaments, and the insertion in the wale direction is polyurethane filament. The polyurethane yarn is partially wrapped by nylon yarn on the way to knit as shown in Figure 2(b). The simplified model in an unstrained state is shown in Figure 3, where the structure consists of wale and course yarns. The structural model of a unit of power net is shown by the square of this figure. The basic structural parameters are as follows: n1, the number of loops measured along a course in a specified width (1 cm) of a power net; n2, the number of loops measured along a wale in a specified length (1 cm) of a power net; L1 and L2, the length of a yarn element in the unit structure in an unstrained state, in the wale and course directions, respectively. They are defined by Equations (1) and (2) using the basic structural constants, n1 and n2 (superscript 1 denotes the wale direction and superscript 2 denotes the course direction): (1)L1=1/n2
(2)L2=1/n1
Figure 3.
Structure model.

sec.title: Biaxial extension
sec.p:
Figure 4 shows the biaxial extension of a unit structure. Figure 4.
Deformation of the unit structure.

The structure of the samples used in the experimental investigation. When the fabric is stretched in the wale and course directions, the tensile forces in these directions are derived as follows: λ1, λ2, stretch ratio applied to the power net in the wale and course directions respectively; the stretch ratio = the strained length of the fabric/the unstrained length of fabric; Ty1, Ty2, the tension of yarns used in the wale and course directions, respectively, where, polyurethane yarn is used in the wale direction and nylon yarn is used in the course direction; and θ is the inclination angle of wale after deformation.

A power net is given by the stretch ratios λ1 and λ2 for a biaxial extension. The values of the stretch ratios are defined as the stretch length divided by the unstrained length, that is, 1 plus tensile strain. When a power net is stretched along two axes by stretch ratios λ1 and λ2, respectively, the inclination angle θ of the wale, yarn stretch ratios λy1 and λy2 are caused, and the tension of yarns Ty1 and Ty2 are induced and, then, the tensile forces of the power net, F1 and F2, in these directions are given.
The equilibrium equation of the forces is (3)Ty2=2Ty1sinθ

In the deformed state, the equilibrium equation (3) of forces must be satisfied. The equilibrium equation holds at the intersection between the wale and course. Where yarn tensions Ty1 and Ty2 are derived by the yarn tensile properties which is a function of yarn stretch ratios λy1 and λy2, respectively, as shown in the following equations: (4)Ty1=f1(λy1) (where we have obtained the measured tensile properties of polyurethane yarn) (5)Ty2=f2(λy2) (where we have obtained the measured tensile properties of nylon yarn), where (6)λy1=λ1/cosθ
(7)λy2=λ2- (L1/L2 )λ1tanθ

Here λy1 and λy2 are given by Equations (6) and (7) by using stretch ratios λ1 and λ2 of the power net and structure constants L1 and L2. By substituting Equations (4) and (5) into Equation (3), θ can be obtained by solving Equation (3) for θ, numerically.

From these relations, the power net structure under the tension can be solved, and the tensile force of the power net is calculated for given yarn stretch ratios, and obtained by the following equations: (8)F1=n1·Ty1cosθ
(9)F2=n2·Ty2 where F1 and F2 are the tensile force of the power net, and n1 and n2 are the density in the wale and course directions, respectively.

sec.title: Experimental details
sec.p:
The basic structural constants of the sample power net are shown in Table 1. These values are required to obtain the tensile properties of a warp insertion knitted fabric using the biaxial extension theory. Table 1.
Sample details
Sample Gauge Yarn counts denier Blend ratio of fabric Fabric
Wale Course polyurethane/nylon Density (1/cm) Weight Thickness
Polyurethane Nylon % wale, n1 course, n2 g/m2 mm
A 28G 280d 50d. 24.5/75.5 15 69 177 0.547
B 28G 140d 40d 24.5/75.5 21 80 191 0.544

The yarn property demanded for calculation is the tensile property. The yarn tensile tensions Ty1 and Ty2 for the wale and course direction, that is, polyurethane and nylon yarns, are given as a function of stretch ratios λy1 and λy2, and the relations are obtained by experiments of yarn tensile properties.

The tensile properties of the yarns are measured by the tensile tester, KES-G1.5 A sample yarn approximately 5 cm in length is reinforced at both ends by gluing pieces of paper with adhesive (epoxy resin) so that it can be clamped by a chuck in a tensile tester. The constant strain rate is 0.004/second. The measuring conditions are a temperature of 20℃ and 65% relative humidity. The yarn tensile behavior is shown in Figures 5 and 6. The relationship between tensile behavior, yarn tension Ty and yarn stretch ratio λy of polyurethane yarn is shown in Figure 5. The tensile behavior of nylon yarn is shown in Figure 6. The regions for calculation of both yarns are within yielding point. Figure 5.
Tensile property of polyurethane yarn.
Figure 6.
Tensile property of nylon yarn.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
The biaxial tensile properties of a power net used to compare the theory are measured by the biaxial tensile tester, KES-G27. Sample length detected for stretch ratio is 10 cm by 10 cm and length detected for force is 6 cm by 6 cm. A constant strain rate is 0.004/second. The measuring conditions are the same as in the yarn experiments. Figures 7 and 8 show the results of sample A and B, respectively. Figure 7.
Biaxial extension properties of power net (sample A). The solid curves show the experimental and the dashed curves show the calculated results.
Figure 8.
Biaxial extension properties of power net (sample B). The solid curves show the experimental and the dashed curves show the calculated results.

Figures 7(a) and 8(a) show the tensile properties in strip biaxial extension deformation mode along the wale direction. This mode is the extension caused by a specimen being stretched in only the wale direction, while the stretch ratio in the course direction, λ2, is kept at 1. The property is predicted well by that theory.

Figures 7(b) and 8(b) show the tensile property, that is, the relationship between the tensile force Fi (i = 1, 2) of a power net and stretch ratio λ1 in equal deformation mode. This mode is equal to the biaxial deformation where the relation stretch ratio (λ1 = λ2) is kept constant through the deformation. Agreement between experimental and calculated results is obtained, especially along the wale direction.

Figures 7(c) and 8(c) show the tensile properties in the strip biaxial extension deformation mode along course direction. This mode is the extension caused by a specimen being stretched in only course direction, while the stretch ratio in the course direction, λ1 is kept at 1. The property is predicted well by that theory, especially along the stretched direction.

Although some errors in these results occurred due to the effects of cross-over friction, this simplified theory of biaxial extension properties of power net might be able to predict the force–stretch ratio relationships along the stretched direction, approximately within the actual use from these results. A new theory considering a friction element will be proposed in the near future.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The biaxial extension property of a power net was analyzed and compared with experimental results obtained using a biaxial tensile tester. Another sample was also inspected, and similar results were given. The theory can predict well, and good agreement was obtained between experimental and calculated results, especially along the stretched direction.

The theory might be useful for designing the power net, and with the results of various previous studies, this will be a powerful tool for the design of the wearing comfort of ladies foundation garments, etc.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
